w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach basic travel words by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases:
season, weather, spring, summer, winter, fall, It is sunny today, seasons are long, days are short, spring/winter/fall/sum

mer is a season, it rains a lot in spring, rain helps flowers grow, flowers grow in spring, in the spring, the weather gets warmer, It’s sunny and hot in the summer, It is windy and cooler in the fall, It snows in the winter, In the summer, it is hot; In t
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for the seasons
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences to describe the different weather in the seasons.
Word List: season, winter, summer, spring, fall
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: Today, we are going to be learning about the different seasons!
Do the actions for the different seasons.
and circle all four pictures that show each season.

Make an action for each of the seasons: hold yourself tight and shiver for winter, fall comically to the ground for fall, spring up from the ground or jump for spring, and wave hand in front of face to indicate being hot for summer.
Circle the different types of weather: rain, snow, sunny, windy, cloudy
Draw a line from the word that describes the weather to the picture.
. Spell it out as you say it. Have the student say the word weather and spell it out.
Circle the different types of weather and say them. Have the student repeat each one with you.
Draw a line from the weather word (i.e. su
nny) to the picture representing the word (i.e. picture of the sun). Encourage and prompt the student to do the same with the other types of weather.
Choose the correct word to describe the weather outside today.
Say the phrase: It is ____________ today.
Visual cue: Have students look outside and describe the weather (this will depend where they are). Show the different pictures of the weather if they need the support.
Visual cue: Use a ruler to help explain how seasons are long. Write out the months for the seasons so that students know that each month is
three-four months long (Fall: September-November; Winter: December-March; Spring: April-May; Summer: June-August.)
Visual cue: Use a clock to show how students how the days become longer and s
hort as the seasons change. For example, show students that in the summer, the sun does not go down until 8-9pm; in the winter, the sun goes down at 4-5pm.
Visual cue: Have students look outside and describe the weather (this will depend where they are).
Show the different pictures of the weather if they need the support.
and circle the picture of spring.
Do the action to show the season,
Say the phrase, “Spring is a season.
on the slide and spell it with the student.
Have student write the word on the screen, and spell it as they write it.
Tell students that that spring is a season. Tell them that this season is where a lot of flowers begin to
and animals come out because it is no longer cold.
or jump up in the air)
and circle the rainy weather in the picture.
Say the phrase, “It rains a lot in the spring.”
Say the phrase, “Rain helps flowers grow.” Circle the flowers in the picture
Say the phrase, “Flowers grow in the spring.”
and spell it out for students.
Say the phrase, “In the spring, the weather gets warmer.”
Do the action for warm weather.
Say and spell out the word
. Have students say the word aloud and write it on the screen or a piece of paper.
Say the phrase, “It rains a lot in the spring.” Circle the rain in the picture. Have students repeat the phrase and circling a
Say the phrase, “Flowers grow in the spring.” Clear the screen and circle the flowers in the picture. Have students repeat the phrase and circling.
Say the phrase, “In the spring, the weather gets warmer.” Have students repeat.
say “warmer”, do the action to show warm (i.e. fanning hand in front of face). Have students repeat the action.

Ask students the question, “What do flowers need to grow?” Emphasize to students that flowers need water and they get this through the rain. Provide students sentence starters to help them say their answers.
and circle the picture of a summer day.
Do the action for the season
Say the phrase, “Summer is a season.”
Write the word summer on the slide and spell it with the student.
Have student write the word on the screen, and spell it as they write it.
Tell students that summer is a season. Tell them that this season is where it starts to get hot and the days become longer.
Act out the word summer. (i.e. wave hand in front of face to show that you are overheating).
Say sunny and circle the sunny weather in the picture.
Say the phrase, “It is sunny and hot in the summer.”
Do the action for hot weather. Do the action for sunny weather.
Say and spell out the word
. Have students say the word aloud and write it on the screen or a piece of paper.
Say the phrase, “It is sunny and hot in the summer.” Circle the sun in the picture. Have students repeat the phrase and circling action.

k students the question, “What can we wear when it is sunny?” Emphasize to students that sunglasses help us see when it is sunny. Circle the sunglasses in a picture or show a picture of sunglasses. Provide students sentence starters to help them say their
and circle the picture of a fall day
Do the action for the season
Say the phrase, “Fall is a season.”
Write the word fall on the slide and spell it with the student.
Have student write the word on the screen, and spell it as they write it.
Tell students that fall is a season. Explain to students that another name for fall is “autumn.” Tell them that this
season is where it starts to get cooler and the leaves change color and fall off the trees.
Act out the word fall (i.e. pretend to fall to the ground).
Say windy and circle the wind in the picture.
Say the phrase, “It is windy and cooler in the fall.”
Do the action for cool or cold weather (i.e. hold and rub hands down arms to show cold).
Say and spell out the word
. Have students say the word aloud and write it on the screen or a piece of paper.
Say the phrase, “It is windy and cooler in the fall.” Circle the windy in the picture.
Have students repeat the phrase and circling action.
Show pictures of people becoming cold in a fall-based picture.
Visual cue: Have students act out the action for cool or cold weather as the word “cooler” is said in the phrase.
Say the word winter and circle the picture of a winter day.
Do the action for the season
Say the phrase, “Winter is a season.”
on the slide and spell it with the student.
Have student write the word on the screen, and spell it as they write it.
Tell students that winter is a season. Tell them that this season is where it becomes a lot colder and snowy.
and circle the snow in the picture.
Say the phrase, “It is snows in the winter.”
Say and spell out the word
. Have students say the word aloud and write it on the screen or a piece of paper.
Say the phrase, “It is snows in the winter.” Have students repeat the phrase.
Practice saying the name and actions for this adjective.
. Have students repeat the adjective and spell it on the screen or on a separate piece of paper.
Visual cue: Have students act out what is like when they are hot. Use the picture to help students correctly act out the word.
Choose the correct adjective and say the phrase,
Circle the picture of the family outside in the summer. Ask for the correct adjective to describe the weather in the picture.
Have the child say the phrase,
Practice saying the name and actions for this adjective.
. Have students repeat the adjective and spell it on the screen or on a separate piece of paper.
Visual cue: Have students act out what is like when they are cold. Use the picture to help students correctly act out the word.
Choose the correct adjective and say the phrase,
Circle the person in the picture. Ask for the correct adjective to describe the weather in the picture.
Have the child say the phrase,
“What should we wear when it is sunny?”
and answer in a complete sentence.
should we wear when it’s sunny?
with intonation. Encourage the child to answer in a complete answer,
it is sunny, we wear sunglasses.
Begin the sentence for the child if needed.
Show students’ different items of clothing that we wear in different weather. Have students
point at the sunglasses when they are shown to answer the question.
“What should we wear when it is cold?”
and answer in a complete sentence.
should we wear when it’s cold?
with intonation. Encourage the child to answer in a complete answer,
it is cold, we wear a hat (gloves and scarves
Begin the sentence for the child if needed.
Show students’ different items of clothing that we wear in different weather. Have students point at the hat, gloves, or scarf, when they are shown to answer the question.
